1.pros: - Good compensation- Good industry- Interesting projects- Good CEO
1.cons: This place will work you to the bone and come performance review time tell you you are ok.60 hour weeks are pretty normal. If you are a hard-working engineer like I am then this won't discourage you. However, the lack of acknowledgment of the work you put in and over-delivering on all of your objectives is very normal at Coinbase. Only about 2 in 10 engineers exceed expectations and a lot of this is based on politics in my experience here.Also if you are looking to join and think the pay equity is a good idea then you have to accept the fact that you can outwork someone by 3x who is doing the bare minimum and they will be compensated in the exact same way as you.

50.pros: One of the fastest moving industries on earth. I don't know another one as nascently disrupting as this, it reminds me of social media and gif economy co.s 10 years ago. Compensation is high but is not rising with inflation so far. You get a lot of freedom in your engineering designs and work, directors are relatively hands off other than status checks and the occasional bit of pressure. Learning about crypto while working is great too. There's a lot of company initiatives to engage us in Defi and a lot of social buzz around that world. We've held a hackathon to help learn about smart contracts, there's channels dedicated to learning, and we even offer a blockchain dev Boot Camp. Work is fully remote with a generous but not limitless international work policy. (60 days every 180 days international)
50.cons: Work life balance is poor. We're moving so fast I feel like I have to work constantly to keen up with deadlines and expectations. Infra is a mess and there are so many hoops it takes literal weeks to set up what I could do in an AWS console in a day. Engineering management (director level) has missed some clear opportunities to deduplicate work leading to back tracking and building things others have already made.

200.desc: If you like your team/mgr+have friends, you'll probably like the day to day. Politics are rough at high levels
200.pros: (Chose a generic job title to post this review)- Lucky to have had a string of decent to good managers, so I felt like I was always heard and relatively supported. - genuinely houses some of the smartest, kindest people I've worked with. - lots of social events and groups pre pandemic. Worked in sf office, felt like people were always friendly, employee resource groups were also good way to meet people. Not sure how I feel about it now that we've been wfh for over a year. - if you have a good team and manager, I think you will largely enjoy the day to day of working here.
200.cons: (Chose a generic job title to post this review)- Unclear promo guidelines on the non-tech side, lots of generic checkboxes but hard to get actionable feedback from managers to get promoted. - lots of whiplash with ever-changing per cycles and reorgs- complicated/unclear comms from senior management- lack of exec team to just take accountability for shitty decisions leads to a lot of mistrust in the company. - assholes who makes the company money or just have a lot of clout can have outsized impact on their team decisions, particularly in eng. - if your manager doesn't hold much influence or power, can be hard for your team to get resourcing. Lot of politicking. - not enough EQ on exec team, but they /think/ they have it. Brian's/executive handling of BLM/blog post last year was just so poor and could have 100% been avoided if anyone on the exec team was a smidge connected to what employees were feeling. I honestly think Brian wouldn't have needed to commit to an external BLM tweet (that he was clearly so pissed about later) if he had just sent out something internally just acknowledging it's a rough time and that the company supported their Black employees, that's all they were asking for lol. Then we lost like 60-70 people over the course of the next few months, even into this year cause people were asked to stay longer and not mention they opted out. - generally a big fan of remote first because of the flexibility for employees, but personally will miss going into the sf office a lot, and not gonna make the trip to south city.

257.desc: Want to dedicate your career to crypto? Coinbase is the best school
257.pros: No need to have prior crypto knowledge or experience for many teams or roles. But if you are considering specializing in crypto or crypto-adjacent tech for your career, and especially if you are getting excited for the vast amount of crypto opportunities in the upcoming decades, Coinbase is the best place to learn, build, and grow. There are tremendous ways to keep up with the latest cutting edge crypto technologies, platforms, tools, and develop with/for them while working with truly talented engineers.
257.cons: The company will continue to scale rapidly in the next few years. Fast growth brings its own challenges in processes, culture, and division of responsibilities across the company.

263.pros: - Overall company outlook is extremely positive. - You get to work on some of the most interesting things you'll probably ever work on, solving some tough and unique problems- ICs are a good crowd - lots of smart, driven people to learn from- Comp and benefits are pretty good. Committed to pay equity and fully remote-first culture. People and Security teams seem to really care about you. - Some good exec hires recently
263.cons: - WLB is nonexistent. Lots going on at once so you have to learn to manage your days to avoid burnout. - Very little room for career growth. Managers seem more interested in getting more done and squeezing more out of you than growing/rewarding good talent and investing in people. Most managers/directors are unnecessary. - Diversity especially in product/eng/design is nonexistent and doesn't seem on track to change (gender, ethnicity, work background etc). We say we care on paper, but management all looks the same so they don't actually make any changes. - Some politics, varies by level. Gets annoying to deal with when you just want to get things done.
263.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  L*****  Product Manager - Jan 21, 2021

264.desc: WLB varies from team to team, and the field is interesting
264.pros: The career track for the engineering got reviewed lately. Also, the company is hiring aggressively. So, you can expect more career opportunities with possible title inflation soon. The executive and management chain got a lot of new faces, mostly ex-Googlers. So, there is a heavy investment on the hiring and retaining the talent. The field itself is interesting and demanding fresh minds. If you are looking for a new challenge it will be a good company to work for. The company is on track to become public. It is possible to get a good return from your RSUs.
264.cons: For the engineering folks: Lots of tech debt that you will face. It is nothing new for any engineer joining a pre-IPO company, but get ready to pay the price of the compromises to take the products and revenue to that levels. Depending on the team that you join WLB can be tricky, try to get the sense from how crazy the hiring manager looks (do your own due diligence: ask the folks inside, do a background check on the team/manager if possible, ask on Blind about the team). Priorities change a lot. Be ready to tackle multiple things in a short period of time. This can be both pro and con depending on your personality. Overall I encourage working for Coinbase.
